text: Could you tell us what the Palestinian camps
were like when you arrived in Lebanon?

Well, now they're much worse
than they were at the time,

but they certainly were bad enough
at the time as well.

If you can imagine refugee camps
where, like you said, people

had been there for 30 years and
now they've been there for 75 years or so.
And you still have -
there's almost no infrastructure.

You have sewage running,
you have electricity and water
cables entangled.

People get killed because they'll be
carrying something tall
and they hit one of these wires.

It's the kind of place that you will have
to see with your own eyes to believe.

I mean, no matter how I 
describe or no matter

how I tell you how bad it is,
it really is something
that you have to see with your own eyes

to believe that this is still possible
now, after 75 years.

I'm trying to understand
why it was so bad.
What is the problem?
Is it the UN administration?
Is it their position within Lebanon?
I think it's a combination of both because
as I'm sure you know, Palestinian refugees
are not allowed to work in Lebanon
in any profession that has a syndicate.

So even if you have a degree
from a school of medicine,

you're not allowed
to practice as a doctor.

And if a doctor works as a taxi driver,
let's say, that's also illegal

because taxi drivers
have their own syndicate as well.
So when you do not
allow people to have a decent income,
they get stuck in a refugee camp

and there is no way
they can improve their circumstances.
